trustfund:
TF098742-Capacity Building for the
            Implementation of Government-wide M&E System

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fifth, Sixth, and
            Seventh Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC) Project for
            Cape Verde were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. One
            key lesson that can be learned from this PRSC series is the
            importance of the need for good indicators to evaluate the
            success of the operation. Indicator data have to be
            available and attributable to government actions, and
            indicators should not simply restate prior actions. One
            particular problem with development policy lending is that
            institutional reform takes time to show effects. The
            operation has also shown the need for strong M&E
            systems. Even if indicators are attributable but data are
            not available, necessary, evidence-based fine-tuning during
            the operation as well as a thorough and fair evaluation upon
            completion of the series is impossible. Investing in country
            Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) capacity, where
            requires, is crucial. Another lesson is that donor
            harmonization can be achieved without surrendering
            flexibility for individual institutions' development
            assessments. In Cape Verde, the budget support group had a
            common donor matrix, bundling clout in policy areas
            considered key by all development partners (e.g. Public
            Financial Management, or PFM reform). In other areas, donors
            maintained flexibility and could focus on their specific
            areas of expertise (e.g. the Portuguese focusing on housing
            and the Bank on State-Owned Enterprise, or SOEs). Within the
            Bank, this approach has found recognition and can be
            recommended to other country units.
